headline.main: Word for Word/Of Little Brain; Ritalin to the Rescue: A Children's Story for Our Time

docs.abstract: Word for Word column excerpts parody of psychology's medicalization of all human experience, analyzing 'disorders' of Winnie the Poor and his friends; drawings; parody comes from professionals in pediatrics department of Dalhousie University in Halifax; Canadian newspapers note that article raises serious questions about frequency with which doctors reach for prescription pad in treating young children (M)
docs.section_name: Health; Education; Books; Week in Review
docs.lead_paragraph: THE the overdiagnosis of learning and behavioral disorders in ever-younger children has gone so far that even psychologists now joke that Huck Finn and Tom Sawyer, were they alive today, would be on Ritalin and in special education for hyperactivity. Similarly, the DSM-IV, the pyschiatrist's diagnostic bible, now includes something called Oppositional Defiant Disorder. Does that mean the Terrible Twos is an illness? In an article titled ''Pathology in the Hundred Acre Wood: a neurodevelopmental perspective on A.A. Milne,'' Sarah E. Shea, Kevin Gordon, Ann Hawkins, Janet Kawchuk and Donna Smith of the department of pediatrics at Dalhousie University in Halifax, Nova Scotia, after an ''exhaustive'' review of the Pooh canon, diagnosed a range of clinical, personality and psychosocial disorders among the major Pooh characters. The article, a parody of psychology's medicalization of all human experience, was printed in the Canadian Medical Association Journal's annual winter lampoon issue.
